sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Welcome back! I’m Jihad Al Sayed. Today, we’re zeroing in on one number that tells you everything about a matrix — the rank. It’s the heartbeat of any linear system.

sections.title: What is Rank?
sections.content: The rank of a matrix is the number of pivot columns in its row echelon form. It’s the dimension of the column space — basically how many linearly independent columns you have.

sections.title: Example Matrix
sections.math:
A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 2 & 3\\2 & 4 & 6\\3 & 6 & 9\end{bmatrix}
→ Row reduce → Only 1 pivot → Rank = 1

sections.title: Why Rank Matters
sections.content: Rank tells you how much information is in your matrix. In data science, high rank = full information. Low rank = compressible, sometimes redundant.

sections.title: Applications in Compression & Systems
sections.content: Used in data compression (low-rank approximations), recommendation engines (SVD), and checking if a linear system has a unique solution.

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: Today you learned how to find the rank, why it matters, and how it ties into the dimension of the column space. Without rank, you’re flying blind with your matrices.
